newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Alcoa Australia says strike won't stop production.
newsitem.headline: Alcoa Australia says strike won't stop production.

text.p: A 24-hour strike at the Western Australia operations of alumimium and bauxite producer Alcoa of Australia Ltd will not stop production, a company spokesman said on Tuesday.

Members of the company's main production union, the Australian Workers Union, as well as members of other unions, walked off the job at Alcoa's main centres on Tuesday in protest against proposed changes to industrial relations laws in the state. Not all unions were out at all sites, but the majority of the group's production employees were out, the spokesman said.

The spokesman said the number of workers involved was not known, although media reports have put the number of striking unionists at 1,500. The strike covers Alcoa's refineries at Wagerup, Pinjarra and Kwinana as well as its three bauxite mines, Willowdale, Huntly and Jarrahdale.
"We'll continue producing. We do not expect this will affect our production. We can handle 24 hours," the spokesman said.
A further strike is set for next week in conjunction with industry action across other industry sectors.
Construction workers in the Pilbara region in the north west of the state earlier ended a 24-hour strike while waterside workers are considering strike action.
